title: Former Home And Away star Ryan Kwanten discusses the death of his former co-star Ben Unwin
text:
Ryan Kwanten has discussed the death of his former Home and Away co-star Ben Unwin earlier this year.

Speaking to news.com.au, Ryan, 42, says that he's come to the realisation that he must 'live for every moment' after seeing the lives of his co-stars end tragically.

'That was just a huge tragedy,' the True Blood actor says of Ben's death. 'I was very upset when I found out.'

'That was just a huge tragedy': Former Home And Away star Ryan Kwanten (pictured) discussed the death of his former co-star Ben Unwin in an interview on Saturday

Ben was found dead on 14 August at the bottom of Minyon Falls near Byron Bay, aged just 41.

The Australian actor also mentioned the death of his True Blood co-star, Nelsan Ellis, who died after complications with heart failure in 2017, aged 39.

Ryan said: 'Towards the end of filming True Blood, we lost Nelsan Ellis, who played Lafayette, too.'

Tragic end: Former Home and Away star Ben Unwin (pictured) was found dead on 14 August at the bottom of Minyon Falls near Byron Bay in August. He was 41

Back then: Ryan, now based in the USA, played Vinnie Patterson from 1997 to 2002 in the long-running Australian soap Home and Away. Pictured in the 1990s

Memories: Ryan is pictured along with co-stars Ben Unwin and Kate Ritchie on the set of Home and Away in 1998

The actor went on: 'I recently went through a huge health scare with my dad, and he's okay now, but it was a real shock to him, and to all of us, to realise how easily he could have lost his life. Some people don't get a second chance.

He concluded: 'I feel like you really need to live for every f**king moment.'

Ryan, now based in the USA, played Vinnie Patterson from 1997 to 2002 in the long-running Australian soap.

Loss: 'That was just a huge tragedy,' Ryan said of Ben's death. 'I was very upset when I found out.' Ben is pictured in 2003

Loss: The Australian actor also mourned the death of his True Blood co-star, Nelsan Ellis, (pictured) who died after complications with heart failure in 2017, aged 39

His comments come after another former co-star, Ben Steel, who played Jude Lawson in the early 2000s, opened up on his depression, and the personal project that saved his life.

Ben, now 43, began making the documentary The Show Must Go On three years ago when he was extremely depressed.

'I was on the brink of suicide,' Ben told The Daily Telegraph.

Ryan went on: 'Some people don't get a second chance. I feel like you really need to live for every f**king moment'

He added: 'I was at the point where I wanted to kill myself. I felt like things within my professional and personal life weren't where I wanted them to be.'

Ben said his documentary highlights to rates of suicide attempts those in the entertainment business endure which are roughly double the national average
